utterances: I love this song.
This was great.
Mr.
Peabo Bryson, thanks for being here with us today.
Ed, I can't thank you enough, and it's always good to speak with you.
Thanks, buddy.

(Singing) Oh, whoa, whoa, whoa, so intense, just the game I play when I want to say `I love you.

(Soundbite of unidentified song)
(Singing) These are the hands that they go reaching for you if you're really there inside.
I'm Farai Chideya.
This is NEWS & NOTES.
Nelly is the latest rapper to try his hand at acting.
He plays a convict in the film ""The Longest Yard."" The movie is a remake of the 1974 prison football comedy of the same name.
This ""Longest Yard"" also reunites ""Saturday Night Live"" alums Adam Sandler and Chris Rock.
(Soundbite of ""The Longest Yard"")
(As Earl Megget) Y'all got a running back?
(As Paul Crewe) Not any good ones.
(As Earl Megget) No disrespect, dude, but any man that can take that kind of beating out here, can't wait to see what he can do in a contact sport.
Nelly helped produce the soundtrack for the movie, but he admits he didn't know much about the original version that starred Burt Reynolds, who also appears in the remake.
Well, you know, it was made in '74, so, you know, it was a little bit before my time, you know.

But I got a chance to see it, like, in the '80s, and then I had a chance to review it, like, a couple of months before we started shooting, you know, to kind of re-up on it and make sure, you know, that I understood what was going on.
And, you know, so it was cool.
Nelly, is this something that you're going to try to hone your craft in?
I mean, you've been pretty smart in all of the things that you've done to this point.
If, indeed, you say, you know, `This wasn't bad.
I could see some other things,' will you start to take acting classes?
Will you do other things?
I think definitely this is something that I see myself in as far as really having a future, and I would, you know, take the correct steps that I would need to.
I think that's part of the reason why I took this role, is that it was something I could relate to easier, you know, as far as me playing football.
You know, I've been playing football since I was 11 and all through high school and just hanging out with the fellows.
You know, that was something I could do, too, so I thought it would be good.
He says there is no longer enough land for them to farm.
Kama says that even when the government provides small grants to help the women plant on what land there is, monkeys and other wild animals destroy the crops.
I asked if he has sought help from the central government.
I had said to him the first time we met if we can provide an explanation to the American public about why we went to war in Iraq, this would be an important public service.
But I fear that I now know less about why we went to war in Iraq after having made this movie than I did at the very beginning.
When you put that to him, that that was purpose of the film, to explain to the American people why the war happened, he wanted to do that as well?
Absolutely.
The film focuses on the Iraq War but you also try to give a fuller portrait of this man.
You trace his political career.
Were there any parts of his biography, of his profile, that opened a door and made you see him in a different way?
Yes.
His failure to engage, meaningfully engage the central issues of our time.
I ask him about the war in Vietnam.
He was in the Oval Office with President Ford, Henry Kissinger as we evacuated the U.S.
embassy in Saigon.
I asked him what'd you learn?
His answer: Some things work out, some things don't.
That didn't.
I ask him about the torture memos that came out of the Bush administration.
He said he never read them.

To me, the most shocking thing about the interview was not his insincerity but quite the opposite; the fact that he was telling the truth but the truth was about a failure to really think about anything.
The film is called ""The Unknown Known,"" which was, you know, one of several machinations of a phrase that he repeated throughout his tenure the second time around.
This is the secretary of defense overseeing Iraq.
The two of you get locked into, at one point, a semantic argument about this phrase, the unknown known.
Were you looking for some particular admission from him that you didn't get?
I think was probably looking for a lot of things that I didn't get.
This expression, which he's famous for - the known known, the known unknown, the unknown unknown, etc., etc. - many people have told me, well, this is really brilliant.
I often ask why.

In one of the press conferences, indeed it's the press conference where he first brings out this idea about the known known and the known unknown, he was asked a question by Jim Miklaszewski, the NBC Pentagon correspondent: What proof, what evidence do you have that Saddam Hussein is in possession of WMD or is giving them to terrorist organizations?
(SOUNDBITE OF MOVIE, ""THE UNKNOWN KNOWN"")
There's no evidence of it.
What's your evidence?
There are known knowns.
There are things we know we know.
We also know there are known unknowns.
That is to say we know there are some things we do not know.
But there are also unknown unknowns.
The ones we don't know we don't know.
And it's a question that he can't answer and won't answer.
The known known becomes an evasion.
He does point out that a lot of the controversial policies of the Bush administration after 9/11 have been perpetuated by the Obama administration.
He does.
I left that in the movie.
But they're all a result of these policies.
Obama has tried to deal with them, not perpetuate them.
Have you heard from Donald Rumsfeld since the film?
I told Donald Rumsfeld that I would show him cuts as we went along and I would encourage him to comment.
He had no control over the film.
But I was interested in his comments.
He wanted me to stress that the policies of the Bush administration were not different than the Clinton administration with respect to Iraq.
I told him I don't agree.
Didn't like all of this attention that was given to Abu Ghraib and to torture, to me, one of the blackest marks against the Bush administration.
This is not about a person who reflects on what he does.
He was a person selling something - selling his belief that he was right and whatever others think, they are wrong.
The film is called ""The Unknown Known."" Errol Morris joined us from our studios at NPR West.
Thanks so much for speaking with us, Mr. Morris.
Thank you very much for having me.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
And you're listening to WEEKEND EDITION from NPR News.
NPR's Juan Williams joins us now.
Hi, Juan.
Hi, Madeleine.
Juan, you just hear the senators, and let's first talk about their assessment of the upcoming election.
Senator Frist surely sounded optimistic, especially about his home state of Tennessee.
And do the facts bear him out?
Right.
The polls, especially over the last few days, indicate that Bob Corker - the Republican candidate, the former mayor of Chattanooga - is extending a lead and it now goes beyond the margin of error.
And also, I think lots of people in the sort of political/professional circle think that Harold Ford's numbers are a little soft because he's an African-American and he's running in the Deep South.
And, you know, people might say they're going to vote for him, how many actually pull the lever is another question.
So take away another maybe three to five points, and it looks like Corker has a pretty strong lead.
Okay.
So Senator Durbin said that there were four very competitive seats that they needed two of, and that was Tennessee and also Missouri, Virginia, and Arizona.
And what's happening in those three?
Well, Virginia looks the best for the Democrats at the moment.
As you heard Senator Durbin say, Jim Webb - the Democrat candidate there running against Senator George Allen, the incumbent - seems to be pulling ahead at the moment.
And it's a big surprise because, Madeleine, we've had discussions here before, and you know that Virginia was thought to be a safe seat for George Allen.
But it's been a really rough go and he has not handled that campaign well with lots of gaffs, racial references, even concern about his Jewish heritage.
Tennessee we've just discussed.
Missouri is so close it's hard to call.
But again, there're very few undecideds.
But historically, you know, voters who are making a last minute decision - break for the challenger, not the incumbent.
And Claire McCaskill has had some very effective ads, especially featuring Michael J.
Fox and the whole Parkinson's controversy.
That will play heavily this weekend on the air.
(Through translator) We asked the government to come and kill the monkeys, but we get no response.
Everyone wants to plant soybeans, she says.
The prices are good and it's easy to grow.
